physical_examinations.relevant_findings: The patient had an absolute eosinophil count of 10.9 × 10^9/L (upper limit of reference range, 0.5 × 10^9/L) with a WBC count of 21.5 × 10^9/L. No blast cells were present in the blood film.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: The absolute eosinophil count increased from 0.09 × 10^9/L two years prior to 10.9 × 10^9/L at the time of presentation.

physical_examinations.relevant_findings: The wife had an absolute eosinophil count of 5.2 × 10^9/L with a WBC count of 12.4 × 10^9/L; her previous CBC two years prior was normal.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: The eosinophil count increased from normal (exact value not specified) to 5.2 × 10^9/L.

physical_examinations.relevant_findings: The first daughter had an absolute eosinophil count of 0.9 × 10^9/L with a WBC count of 9.7 × 10^9/L. Stool microscopy revealed only D. fragilis.
The second daughter had an absolute eosinophil count of 0.5 × 10^9/L with a WBC count of 6.6 × 10^9/L; six stool specimens over two months did not reveal any parasites.

The sister-in-law recorded severe diarrhea (>6 episodes per day), abdominal bloating, and a 7-kg (12%) weight loss over a one-month period. Her absolute eosinophil count was 4.7 × 10^9/L after three days of symptomatic treatment.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: Eosinophil count prior to treatment with metronidazole was 4.7 × 10^9/L, but no prior counts are provided.

physical_examinations.relevant_findings: After treatment with metronidazole, there was a marked reduction in peripheral eosinophilia in all treated cases, and symptoms resolved in case 1 and case 5.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: All cases returned to normal eosinophil counts (0.2 × 10^9/L) and remained symptom-free twelve months post-treatment.
